citations.narrative:
Complete acquisition records for 2 cavy and complete disposition records for 1 capybara, 2 pigs, 1 rabbit, 2 ferrets and 1
chinchilla were not available during this inspection. Not maintaining accurate records for acquisition and disposition and
records of animals on hand can result in the inability to trace the movement of animals as required by the regulations. Per
the regulations, every dealer other than operators of auction sales and brokers to whom animals are consigned, and
exhibitor shall make, keep, and maintain records or forms which fully and correctly disclose the information contained in
parts i - vii in this section concerning animals other than dogs and cats, purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held,
leased, or otherwise in his or her possession or under his or her control, or which is transported, sold, euthanized, or
otherwise disposed of by that dealer or exhibitor. The records shall include any offspring born of any animal while in his or
her possession or under his or her control.

The following animals were present in an active construction area: 3 red kangaroo, 1 wallaby, 1 eastern grey kangaroo.
Active power tool use was occurring with the animals present in the enclosure when the inspector arrived at the premises.
One of the red kangaroo was observed picking 1.5 inch screws out of a screw container with its mouth while another red
kangaroo was observed grazing up against live electrical cords. Not securing animals away from an active construction
site can allow the animals access to items unfit for consumption and poses a significant risk of electrocution. Per the
regulations, handling of all animals shall be done as expeditiously and carefully as possible in a manner that does not
cause trauma, overheating, excessive cooling, behavioral stress, physical harm, or unnecessary discomfort. Corrected
during inspection.

Two children were observed playing in public contact area of the zoo containing 5 alpacas. There was no attendant
present with the children in this area. Unsupervised children in areas with loose animals can result in harm to the animals
and/or the people. Per the regulations, A responsible, knowledgeable, and readily identifiable employee or attendant must
be present at all times during periods of public contact.

The two lemur and one capuchin enclosures had build-up of dark grime on resting shelves and the floor. Not maintaining
appropriate levels of cleanliness in areas utilized by scent-marking non-human primates can result in excessive build-up
of materials that can increase the disease risk for the animals contained within. Per the regulations, hard surfaces with
which nonhuman primates come in contact must be spot-cleaned daily and sanitized in accordance with § 3.84 of this
subpart to prevent accumulation of excreta or disease hazards. If the species scent mark, the surfaces must be sanitized
or replaced at regular intervals as determined by the attending veterinarian in accordance with generally accepted
professional and husbandry practices. Correct by 10March2023.

Exposed electrical cords and/or lights were accessible to the animals in several enclosures. The animals within these
enclosures included: 4 red kangaroo, 1 wallaby, 1 eastern grey kangaroo, 1 camel, 1 serval, 1 coati, and 1 fennec fox.
Having access to electrical items poses a significant risk of electrocution to the animals. Per the regulations, the facility
must be constructed of such material and of such strength as appropriate for the animals involved. The indoor and
outdoor housing facilities shall be structurally sound and shall be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from
injury and to contain the animals.

Multiple enclosures contained excessive amounts of standing water. Animals contained in these enclosures included the
camel, capybara, cattle, pigs and goats, Not having sufficient dry areas can result in increased disease risk for the
animals. Per the regulations, a suitable method shall be provided to rapidly eliminate excess water. Correct by April 3,
2023.

Excessive amounts of feces were present in the housing area of the capybara. Inadequate removal of feces in an
enclosure can lead to excessive pest issues and poses a disease risk to the animal. Per the regulations, excreta shall be
removed from primary enclosures as often as necessary to prevent contamination of the animals contained therein and to
minimize disease hazards and to reduce odors. Correct by 05March2023.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
End Section

narrative:
2.75(b)(1)  Repeat
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
Complete acquisition records for 2 cavy and complete disposition records for 1 capybara, 2 pigs, 1 rabbit, 2 ferrets and 1 
chinchilla were not available during this inspection.  Not maintaining accurate records for acquisition and disposition and 
records of animals on hand can result in the inability to trace the movement of animals as required by the regulations.  Per 
the regulations, every dealer other than operators of auction sales and brokers to whom animals are consigned, and 
exhibitor shall make, keep, and maintain records or forms which fully and correctly disclose the information contained in 
parts i - vii in this section concerning animals other than dogs and cats, purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, 
leased, or otherwise in his or her possession or under his or her control, or which is transported, sold, euthanized, or 
otherwise disposed of by that dealer or exhibitor. The records shall include any offspring born of any animal while in his or 
her possession or under his or her control. 
2.131(b)(1) 
   
Handling of animals. 
The following animals were present in an active construction area: 3 red kangaroo, 1 wallaby, 1 eastern grey kangaroo.  
Active power tool use was occurring with the animals present in the enclosure when the inspector arrived at the premises. 
One of the red kangaroo was observed picking 1.5 inch screws out of a screw container with its mouth while another red

kangaroo was observed grazing up against live electrical cords.  Not securing animals away from an active construction 
site can allow the animals access to items unfit for consumption and poses a significant risk of electrocution. Per the 
regulations, handling of all animals shall be done as expeditiously and carefully as possible in a manner that does not 
cause trauma, overheating, excessive cooling, behavioral stress, physical harm, or unnecessary discomfort. Corrected 
during inspection. 
2.131(d)(2)  Repeat
   
Handling of animals. 
Two children were observed playing in public contact area of the zoo containing 5 alpacas.  There was no attendant 
present with the children in this area. Unsupervised children in areas with loose animals can result in harm to the animals 
and/or the people. Per the regulations, A responsible, knowledgeable, and readily identifiable employee or attendant must 
be present at all times during periods of public contact. 
3.75(c)(3) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
The two lemur and one capuchin enclosures had build-up of dark grime on resting shelves and the floor.  Not maintaining 
appropriate levels of cleanliness in areas utilized by scent-marking non-human primates can result in excessive build-up 
of materials that can increase the disease risk for the animals contained within. Per the regulations, hard surfaces with 
which nonhuman primates come in contact must be spot-cleaned daily and sanitized in accordance with § 3.84 of this 
subpart to prevent accumulation of excreta or disease hazards. If the species scent mark, the surfaces must be sanitized 
or replaced at regular intervals as determined by the attending veterinarian in accordance with generally accepted 
professional and husbandry practices.  Correct by 10March2023. 
3.125(a)  Repeat
   
Facilities, general.

Exposed electrical cords and/or lights were accessible to the animals in several enclosures. The animals within these 
enclosures included: 4 red kangaroo, 1 wallaby, 1 eastern grey kangaroo, 1 camel, 1 serval, 1 coati, and 1 fennec fox.  
Having access to electrical items poses a significant risk of electrocution to the animals.  Per the regulations, the facility 
must be constructed of such material and of such strength as appropriate for the animals involved. The indoor and 
outdoor housing facilities shall be structurally sound and shall be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from 
injury and to contain the animals. 
3.127(c) 
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
Multiple enclosures contained excessive amounts of standing water. Animals contained in these enclosures included the 
camel, capybara, cattle, pigs and goats,  Not having sufficient dry areas can result in increased disease risk for the 
animals. Per the regulations,  a suitable method shall be provided to rapidly eliminate excess water. Correct by April 3, 
2023. 
3.131(a) 
   
Sanitation. 
Excessive amounts of feces were present in the housing area of the capybara.  Inadequate removal of feces in an 
enclosure can lead to excessive pest issues and poses a disease risk to the animal.  Per the regulations, excreta shall be 
removed from primary enclosures as often as necessary to prevent contamination of the animals contained therein and to 
minimize disease hazards and to reduce odors. Correct by 05March2023. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives. 
 
End Section

species.common: DOMESTIC PIG / POTBELLY PIG / MICRO PIG

species.scientific: Canis lupus X C. l. familiaris
